document.masterDocTitle: Revision of world Austroterobiinae and Parasaphodinae (Hymenoptera: Chalcidoidea: Pteromalidae), parasitoids of giant scales (Hemiptera: Coccoidea: Monophlebidae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Revision of world Austroterobiinae and Parasaphodinae (Hymenoptera: Chalcidoidea: Pteromalidae), parasitoids of giant scales (Hemiptera: Coccoidea: Monophlebidae)

subSubSection.paragraph:
Austroterobia gatesi
superficially resembles
A . achterbergi
in colour, as well as in head and mesosomal structure; however it differs from the latter species in having complete notauli ( Fig. 17 ), distinctly pedicellate funicular segments ( Fig. 16 ), and a different wing structure, i.e. without a speculum and with a hyaline break on the parastigma ( Fig. 20 ).

materialsCitation.collectorName: J S Noyes & J A Asofeifa'

paragraph.materialsCitation:
Material examined. Type material. Holotype ♀ (deposited in UCD ) [entire; on triangular card].
COSTA RICA :
‘ Costa Rica : Puntarenas Los Patos Par. Nac. Corcovado, 8°33’N 83°30’W
200m
,
1-9.III.00
MT/YPT, J S Noyes & J A Asofeifa’ , ‘
Austroterobia S. L. Heydon 2002
’.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 11, 12.
Austroterobia gatesi
, holotype ♀: 11, habitus, lateral view; 12, habitus, dorsal view.

FIGURES 13–20.
Austroterobia gatesi
, holotype ♀: 13, head, frontal view; 14, head, dorsal view; 15, head, lateral view; 16, antenna; 17, mesosoma, dorsal view; 18, mesosoma, lateral view; 19, propodeum and petiole, dorsal view; 20, fore wing.

subSubSection.paragraph: Mesosoma length subequal to width (55:52), width about 1.4× height (41:30). Mesoscutum width 3.15× length (41:13). Mesoscutellum length 0.95× width (20:21). Propodeum length 0.45× mesoscutellum length (9:20). Fore wing length about 1.9× width (96:51); MV about 1.2× SV (18.0:15.5); PV about 1.7× MV (31:18).
Remarks. This is the first record of the subfamily Austroterobiinae in the Neotropical region; it is highly probable that other species will be discovered when more material is examined.
Etymology. Named in honour of Dr. Michael Gates ( USNM ), for his contribution to the systematics of Chalcidoidea .
